item.title: On Clojure (part 3)
item.description: QT Designer with Clojure So, as promised, here’s a few notes on how I am using Qt Designer with Clojure. Some important things to remember: You must use Qt Designer with the QtJambi plugins installed. The easiest way to do this is to run designer.sh (Linux / UNIX / Mac OS X) or designer.bat (Windows) from the distribution folder that QtJambi came in. If you’ve got QtJambi installed as a package under Linux then you may need to check that the QtJambi plugins are correctly installed , they weren’t in my case.

item.title: On Clojure (part 2)
item.description: Distributing QtJambi with Clojure. How to bundle up Clojure programs for distribution One of the questions I’ve seen coming up a few times is how to distribute clojure programs. The obvious answer is to build executable JAR files. A while ago I produced a simple database application for my girlfriends recruitment business, NRecruit. I developed this using Clojure on my Arch Linux based laptop, and deployed to her MacBook running OS X Leopard.
